fields.headline: On the 20th Century – review
fields.bodyText: Not a history of the last century, but a madcap musical set among theatre folk on a night train to New York, Cy Coleman, Betty Comden and Adolph Green's show was written in 1978, but takes place in the 30s and borrows from the screwball comedies of the 50s and late 19th-century operetta. Essentially this entertaining dog's dinner is a backstage musical on wheels as bigwig producer Oscar Jaffee hightails it out of Chicago after his latest disaster in what is becoming a trainwreck of a career. But Jaffee knows that his former protege and lover, Lily Garland, now a Hollywood star, is on the train on her way to appear in a stage show being mounted by his former office boy-turned-successful-producer. If Oscar can only get her signature on a contract, his own career will be revived. Religious fruitcakes, vain matinee idols and a train full of would-be playwrights ensure that havoc ensues as Oscar uses fair means and foul to win Lily to his cause. Like Comden and Green's Bells Are Ringing, which was such a hit at this address a couple of months ago, this is delicious nonsense, but while it has plenty of similar wise-cracking wit, it doesn't have the warmth. None of the characters are particularly likable, let alone lovable. That said, Ryan McBryde's production and clever staging, which uses just a couple of doors and some trunks and suitcases to ingenious effect, works up a head of steam and offers plenty of fun, particularly in its second half, as the farce unravels. It's impossible to dislike a musical that includes a barnstorming number entitled She's a Nut, and the cast deliver an evening that may not quite be champagne but which has plenty of fizz. Until 15 January. Box office: 020-7261 9876.
